Award.AwardTitle: Food, Ethnicity, and Place: Feeding Families and Nourishing Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project investigates the everyday food practices of children and their families in various urban neighborhoods in an effort to better understand the relationships between food, ethnicity, and place. Although scholars have noted the importance of food environments in shaping food choices and health outcomes, research to date tends to compartmentalize place-level factors and ignore the relational qualities of place. The presumably less healthy food habits of low-income and minority populations are typically explained by lower access to affordable and healthy food. However, food practices, ethnicity and place are mutually constituted through a web of social, political, economic and emotional relations within homes and communities. These connections between food, ethnicity and place remain poorly theorized and need to be more systematically substantiated through empirical and comparative analysis. In particular, there is limited research on the ways that family dynamics and children influence these relationships. The project addresses this knowledge gap by investigating everyday family food practices associated with the acquisition, preparation and consumption of food, intra-household negotiations of these practices and responses to diverse and changing local food environments in several neighborhoods in San Diego representing predominantly Italian, East African and Mexican communities. Particular attention is given to the enabling/constraining capacities of place in shaping social reproduction and children's agency in influencing family practices, resisting gendered divisions of labor, and creating new bridges between home and other environments. Quantitative and qualitative approaches are integrated to collect and analyze data. In each site, the research team will conduct food audits, map food resources and census data, and interview store and restaurant owners, school and public officials, and leaders of community-based organizations to generate a better understanding of the local food environment. This will inform extensive ethnographic research centered on children and their families to collect data on everyday food practices and the dynamic relationships between food, place, and ethnic identities. Data will be collected through food-related activities in schools, participant observation, focus groups and subsequent family interviews of children and parents/guardians both separately and together.

This project will be the basis of a new community-based research and service-learning curriculum for undergraduates and will provide training for graduate students. The research team will work closely with local organizations in identifying needs and resources, developing solutions, and disseminating findings. This project will also advance the literature on food practices by situating them in place-specific social relations. Doing so, it will contribute to research on environmental context of food consumption by considering the relational qualities of place, their embeddedness in social relations, and the ways these spatialized relations produce unique food environments and influence food choices. It will expand and further connect literatures on children and social reproduction by bringing children firmly into the negotiated process of social reproduction through our ethnographic work. In addition, the research will contribute knowledge on race by generating better understandings of the spatiality of 'ethnic' food practices and the social construction and materiality of race.

This project is cofunded by the Geography and Spatial Sciences and Cultural Anthropology Programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of our research were to generate a better understanding of: (a) intra-urban differences in food environments, (b) ethnic variations in family and children food practices and (c) dynamic relationships between food, ethnicity and place. 

Our project began with intensive data collection and fieldwork, including audits of food retailers, participant observation, media content searches, surveys and semi-structured interviews of community stakeholders, adolescents, parents, and ethnic market owners.

We used these quantitative and qualitative data to analyze the food environments of three diverse urban neighborhoods in San Diego and interpret their residents’ food practices. With quantitative data, we mapped access to fresh, affordable, healthy and culturally appropriate food and visualized daily food activity spaces of young people and their families. These patterns were analyzed in relation to individual and neighborhood socio-economic characteristics, including race, immigration, poverty, and gentrification. The food habits of young people and their families, the business practices of store owners, and the activities of food-focused organizations were interpreted in that context.

Our results contribute to research in geography and other related disciplines, such as anthropology, sociology, food studies, urban studies, public health and nutrition by generating new critical knowledge in four areas:

(1)   Food Desert and Food Insecurity: Our results challenge common understandings of “food desert” by revealing the heterogeneity of local food environments. Small markets, which are typically ignored in measures of food deserts, play an important role in the everyday food geographies of people with limited mobility and income. Labeling neighborhoods as food deserts and failing to acknowledge existing local resources lead to place “stigmatization”, stifling community-based solutions and failing to address underlying causes of food insecurity.

(2)   Alternative Urban Food Systems and Gentrification: Conceptualizing community gardens and farmers’ markets as socially produced places highlights the diversity of motives underlying the localization of food systems. Our spatial analysis of the distribution of these sites in San Diego, along with qualitative case studies, reveal their role in promoting gentrification – a phenomenon masked by discourses of community and social justice.

(3)   Ethnic Markets: Interviews with owners and consumers reveal the central place of small ethnic markets in the everyday life of ethnically diverse communities. Results highlight their positive role in promoting community food security, stimulating economic vitality, encouraging inter-cultural encounters, and creating a sense of place. Yet, many ethnic markets are struggling financially, suggesting an area for policy intervention.

(4)   Young People and Nutrition: Food as a Journey: Our findings challenges the geographic determinism implicit in food environment research and the universality of mainstream nutrition. Working with young people, we show that the relationship between place and food is fluid and dynamic – a journey through which they navigate contradictions in food norms and meanings across places. Although structured by social and economic relations and governed by biopolitics and emotions, young people’s daily engagements with their food environments reveal agency in making food choices, expressing identities and connecting to place.

These findings have been published in 5 journal articles, 11 book chapters, and a policy report. They have been reported in university publications, the local press and our project website. PIs Joassart-Marcelli and Bosco have edited a peer-reviewed volume, Food and Place: A Critical Exploration, which rests heavily on this research project and includes many chapters co-authored by the PIs and graduate students. The two PIs gave 18 presentations at academic conferences and colloquia. Graduate students also presented their contribution at academic conferences.

The project provided training opportunities for 6 MA and 2 PhD students, who worked as research assistants. It created synergy around food justice and sustainability at SDSU and provided data and inspiration to other students, including 10 MA and 3 PhD advised by the PIs. It also included an important undergraduate education component: dozens of students took related classes, including geography of food (GEOG340) and food justice (GEOG440), and participated in research via a newly developed course entitled community-based geographic research (GEOG590). The geography curriculum has been enhanced by these additions and plans are underway to add an urban food system specialization in the Urban Studies program chaired by the PIs. The broader SDSU community also benefitted from presentations and a yearlong food film series, which provided networking opportunities and led to collaboration on six research proposals building on this project.  

Finally, it is our hope that local organizations, policy makers, and residents of our study neighborhoods have also benefited from our research, which sought to inform the development of a more sustainable and just local food system. Our data collection was designed with input from community groups and our results were shared with them. The data have been used to support a "good food" district, assistance to small markets and ethnic retailers, food security initiatives, and youth food activism, while cautioning against the risks of social exclusion and gentrification. 

 


Last Modified: 02/08/2017
Modified by: Pascale Joassart-Marcelli

Images (1 of )
  • Using GPS-tagged photography and photo-voice interviews, we analyzed the everyday food activity space of young people and learned how they navigate their complex food environments.
    Bosco, F.J., Joassart-Marcelli, P., and O'Neal, B.
    Copyrighted
    Pascale Joassart-Marcelli
    Young People's Food Journeys
  • This image contrasts common indicators of the food environment (which typically include access to supermarkets) with the fine-grained data provided by our audits. While panel a suggests the existence of a "food desert", panel b paints a different picture.
    Joassart-Marcelli, P., Rossiter, J.S., and Bosco, F.J.
    Copyrighted
    Pascale Joassart-Marcelli
    Walking Distance to Food Stores
  • This image includes pictures taken by high school students who participated in our study. They reflect the conflicting messages that young people receive about food and the complexity of their relationship to food.
    Bosco, F.J., Joassart-Marcelli, P., and O'Neal, B.
    Copyrighted
    Pascale Joassart-Marcelli
    Young People's Contradictory Food Environments
  • This image was produced for our 2014 report on Southeastern San Diego's Food Landscape. It highlights disparities in access to fresh produce within the neighborhood. These findings have been used by Project New Village (local nonprofit) in their efforts to improve food security in the area.
    Joassart-Marcelli, P., Bosco, F.J., and Delgado, E.
    Copyrighted
    Pascale Joassart-Marcelli
    Food Stores, by Fresh Produce Availability
  • This map shows the concentration of farmers markets and community gardens in affluent coastal areas and gentrifying neighborhoods of San Diego. Urban planners, developers, business owners, investors, and policy makers are embracing these alternative food spaces as a strategy for urban renewal.
    Joassart-Marcelli, P. and Bosco, F.J.
    Copyrighted
    Pascale Joassart-Marcelli
    Alternative Food Spaces and Gentrification
  • This word cloud illustrates the type of foods that young people in our study typically purchased after school at local markets. Almost half of the students skipped the free lunch; these snacks were the first food they had since breakfast.
    Bosco, F.J., Joassart-Marcelli, P., and O'Neal, B.
    Copyrighted
    Pascale Joassart-Marcelli
    Favorite Snacks from the School Neighborhood

We used these quantitative and qualitative data to analyze the food environments of three diverse urban neighborhoods in San Diego and interpret their residents? food practices. These patterns were analyzed in relation to individual and neighborhood socio-economic characteristics, including race, immigration, poverty, and gentrification. (2) Alternative Urban Food Systems and Gentrification: Conceptualizing community gardens and farmers? markets as socially produced places highlights the diversity of motives underlying the localization of food systems. (3) Ethnic Markets: Interviews with owners and consumers reveal the central place of small ethnic markets in the everyday life of ethnically diverse communities. Working with young people, we show that the relationship between place and food is fluid and dynamic – a journey through which they navigate contradictions in food norms and meanings across places. PIs Joassart-Marcelli and Bosco have edited a peer-reviewed volume, Food and Place: A Critical Exploration, which rests heavily on this research project and includes many chapters co-authored by the PIs and graduate students.
